author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Counting on ‘Endemic’: The Travel Industry Readies for a Potentially New Phase
description: A growing call to consider the coronavirus a permanent fixture in our lives is resonating among travel operators. But that would not necessarily mean the virus is no longer dangerous.
content: In Britain and Denmark most coronavirus restrictions have been lifted, including mask mandates; Austria and the Netherlands have eased lockdown measures despite surges in cases, and in late January, the European Union recommended that vaccinated residents should not be required to undergo testing or quarantine when traveling between the 27 member states.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: New York’s Hospitals Emerge, Resilient, From Omicron Wave
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 6, 2022.
content: “Our hospitals did come under strain, particularly emergency departments, and — a little bit less so — our intensive care units compared to prior surges. But they held the line.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 7, 2022
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Queen Elizabeth Paves the Way for Camilla to One Day Be Called Queen
description: On the eve of the 70th anniversary of the start of her reign, Elizabeth said she wanted the Duchess of Cornwall to hold the title of Queen Consort once Prince Charles is king.
content: On Saturday, the eve of the 70th anniversary of her accession to the throne, Queen Elizabeth II paved the way for Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall, to be called a queen once Prince Charles becomes king of Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Macron Tries to Avert a European War and Reshape European Security
description: The French president’s shuttle diplomacy this week in Moscow and Kyiv will be a delicate exercise, given European reservations and American resolve.
content: PARIS — The standoff with Russia over Ukraine enters a critical phase this week. The United States has snapped NATO to attention and moved forces east. Moscow has readied still more forces on the Ukraine border. But beneath those tensions, diplomatic avenues are being feverishly explored and the outlines of potential solutions, still amorphous, may be taking form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and David E. Sanger
title: U.S. Warns of Grim Toll if Putin Pursues Full Invasion of Ukraine
description: Biden administration officials told lawmakers that a large-scale Russian invasion could kill as many as 50,000 civilians and prompt a refugee crisis in Europe.
content: WASHINGTON — Senior Biden administration officials told lawmakers this past week that they believed the Russian military had assembled 70 percent of the forces it would need to mount a full invasion of Ukraine, painting the most ominous picture yet of the options that Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, has created for himself in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James S. Russell
title: Why Does the Demolition of a Marcel Breuer House Matter?
description: The Geller house embodied the optimistic, now-vanished values of postwar suburbia: technological progress and a lifestyle built around children’s needs.
content: LAWRENCE, N.Y. — “Are people going to care about one little house?” asked Elizabeth Waytkus, who had been alerted some weeks ago to the possibility that a once-celebrated house by the architect Marcel Breuer would be demolished. She is the executive director of Docomomo US, a nonprofit organization that promotes the preservation of modern structures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: 7 Thoughtful Reader Responses on Ending Online Church
description: Readers had strong feelings about last week’s newsletter. Here are some of the most compelling replies.
content: There was a huge response to last week’s newsletter, where I argued that churches should phase out their livestream services. I received thousands of emails and other replies online, many of which were beautiful and profound. You’ve given me a lot to think about!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter W. Galbraith
title: Kids in ISIS Detention Camps Don’t Deserve This Fate
description: The conditions are horrific and dangerous. And they’re breeding grounds for radicalization and the next generation of ISIS adherents.
content: “I am scared I’ll die anytime,” the teenager said in his 11-second voice message. “Please help me.” He was a human shield for ISIS, one of about 150 foreign minors taken hostage in a prison in northeastern Syria last month. Even if he survived the siege, his prospects were bleak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: What Is Luge? What Is Skeleton?
description: Both are death-defying sledding events. In skeleton, athletes go headfirst.
content: Here’s how to keep the two sledding sports straight:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Biden’s ‘Friend’ Is the Enemy
description: The president suffers from the same blind spot as other white liberal leaders throughout history.
content: I don’t know Joe Biden personally. I’ve never met the man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: A Strong Jobs Report
description: The jobs numbers were better than expected. But Meta’s earnings were weaker, sending its stock plunging. CNN’s top executive resigned. And the Olympics have begun.
content: The economy added 467,000 jobs in January despite record levels of coronavirus cases, the Department of Labor reported on Friday. Employers continued to add jobs at roughly the same rate as they did in December. Data quirks make the jobs numbers particularly difficult to accurately interpret in January, and the labor force shrank, suggesting that Omicron may have kept some people from looking for work. But economists said that the strong jobs report was a good sign. “Clearly something is different about this surge,” said Julia Pollak, chief economist for the career site ZipRecruiter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: ‘Very Cold People’ Makes Something Beautiful Out of a Painful Childhood
description: The memoirist Sarah Manguso’s first novel is about a young girl’s life in a small, snowy New England town.
content: VERY COLD PEOPLEBy Sarah Manguso191 pages. Hogarth. $26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino, Safiullah Padshah and Jim Huylebroek
title: Afghanistan’s Health Care System Is Collapsing Under Stress
description: Hospitals and clinics are struggling to hold up amid a cash shortage and a vast surge of malnutrition and disease. By one estimate, 90 percent may close in the next few months.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Amena, 7 months old, lay silently in her hospital crib amid the mewling of desperately ill infants in the malnutrition ward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Omicron’s surge helped clarify the Pfizer vaccine’s efficacy in young children, a company board member says.
description: At the urging of the federal government, Pfizer and its partner BioNTech applied last week for authorization for two doses of its Covid vaccine to children ages 4 and younger.
content: By now, the Omicron wave of the coronavirus has crested in much of the United States. But the size of the wave, which broke records for national cases and hospitalizations, has given regulators and scientists an opportunity to better assess vaccine efficacy in children ages 6 months to 4 years old, Dr. Scott Gottlieb, a former commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: How a Butterfly Refuge at the Texas Border Became the Target of Far-Right Lies
description: Becoming the focus of conspiracy theories about child sex trafficking has caused the National Butterfly Center to shut its doors for now.
content: MISSION, Texas — For nearly two decades, the National Butterfly Center has provided a place of wonder along the banks of the Rio Grande, attracting curious visitors and nature enthusiasts from around the country to watch delicate creatures like the xami hairstreak float over flowers and alight on logs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: U.S. overnight broadcast coverage includes figure skating, snowboarding and skiing.
description: In the women’s slopestyle snowboarding final, Jamie Anderson of the United States vies to add a third gold medal to her collection.
content: The 2022 Winter Games are underway, and U.S. broadcast coverage continues overnight with snowboarding, skiing and speedskating. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: John Vinocur, Foreign Correspondent and Editor, Dies at 81
description: After decades as a reporter for The A.P. and The Times, he became executive editor of The International Herald Tribune and a columnist on world affairs.
content: John Vinocur, a former foreign correspondent for The New York Times and The Associated Press who reported with equal gusto about the latest Cold War crisis in Eastern Europe and the best bouillabaisse in Marseille before becoming executive editor of The International Herald Tribune, died on Sunday in Amsterdam. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: How Yiddish Scholars Are Rescuing Women’s Novels From Obscurity
description: Works written decades ago, often by female Jewish immigrants, were dismissed as insignificant or unmarketable. But in the past several years, translators devoted to the literature are making it available to a wider readership.
content: In “Diary of a Lonely Girl, or the Battle Against Free Love,” a sendup of the socialists, anarchists and intellectuals who populated New York’s Lower East Side in the early 20th century, Miriam Karpilove writes from the perspective of a sardonic young woman frustrated by the men’s advocacy of unrestrained sexuality and their lack of concern about the consequences for her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Why the World’s Best Skiers Don’t Always Win at the Olympics
description: Nothing solidifies a skier’s status like an Olympic medal. But winning one depends not only on training, but also luck and the right conditions.
content: YANQING, China — At this point, Mikaela Shiffrin has gotten used to a certain rhythm to her life. Every four years, the world appears on her doorstep and asks how many medals she is going to win at the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was Feeling Tired and Frustrated as the Train Rumbled North’
description: Consolation of a sort on the A train, a kindred spirit on the F and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: At luge, a familiar name helps a Georgian family move past a tragedy.
description: Saba Kumaritashvili competed in men’s singles 12 years after his cousin, Nodar, was killed in a training accident at the Vancouver Games.
content: Nodar Kumaritashvili was on the verge of becoming the first Georgian luger to participate in the Olympics when he died in a training accident hours before the opening ceremony of the 2010 Vancouver Games. Kumaritashvili lost control of his sled, sailed off the track and collided with a metal post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Senter, Sophie Kasakove and Sergio Olmos
title: ‘We Need Something Different’: Protesters March in Minneapolis After Police Killing
description: A large crowd of demonstrators gathered downtown days after the fatal shooting of Amir Locke, 22.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Chanting the name of Amir Locke, a large crowd of protesters marched in frigid weather in downtown Minneapolis on Saturday to voice exasperation and anger over the conduct of law enforcement officers, nearly two years after the murder of George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Teenage Inmates in Syria Lack Food and Medicine, Aid Group Says
description: UNICEF was given the first glimpse of teenage detainees at a prison attacked by ISIS two weeks ago in northeastern Syria.
content: QAMISHLI, Syria — Child detainees at a prison in northeast Syria that was attacked by ISIS two weeks ago are injured, hungry and thirsty, according to the first international aid worker to see them since the siege.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 6, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Feb. 6, 2022.
content: An article on page 12 this weekend about a production of “Swan Lake” by Miami City Ballet misidentifies the character that Nathalia Arja referred to as “almost not there” in the lakeside pas de deux. It was Benno, not Siegfried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Zoi Sadowski-Synnott Leads Slopestyle’s New Guard
description: The three medalists at these Olympics affirmed the arrival of the next generation of snowboarders, a group that is supplanting the two-time gold medalist Jamie Anderson.
content: It was the final run of the competition, the final jump of the run. Out of the blue sky came Zoi Sadowski-Synnott, a 20-year-old from New Zealand, and now the undisputed queen of slopestyle snowboarding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Germany’s ‘Invisible’ Chancellor Heads to Washington Amid Fierce Criticism
description: Olaf Scholz will try to repair Germany’s credibility in the Ukraine crisis when he meets President Biden on Monday. Next on his agenda: Kyiv and Moscow.
content: BERLIN — One headline asked, “Where is Olaf Scholz?” A popular magazine mocked the German chancellor’s “art of disappearance.” And his ambassador in Washington wrote home that Germany was increasingly seen as an unreliable ally in a leaked memo that was all the buzz this past week and began with the words: “Berlin, we have a problem.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: India’s Youth Squad Sweeps to Victory in Cricket World Cup
description: The team’s ability to clinch a record fifth under-19 title despite a Covid outbreak underscored the vast pool of talent in India as it consolidates its place as a powerhouse in the sport.
content: India’s youth team defeated England to win the Men’s Under-19 Cricket World Cup on Saturday, overcoming a Covid outbreak that briefly depleted its ranks and holding its nerves in a tightly fought final contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: The Covid Policy That Really Mattered Wasn’t a Policy
description: Public health is rooted in the soil of trust.
content: If the C.D.C. had recommended better masks from the beginning, how many people would have worn them and for how long? If the Biden administration had flooded stores with cheap rapid tests, would people have used them? If boosters had been pushed earlier, and more loudly, would the United States no longer trail peer nations in vaccinations?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: A positive coronavirus test, a trip home, and then a surprise win for Australia.
description: A last-minute ruling allowed Tahli Gill of Australia’s mixed doubles curling team to compete.
content: Just getting on the ice on Sunday felt like a victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Woman ‘Tricked’ to Believe She Was a D.E.A. Agent Trainee, Official Says
description: A man in Oregon duped the woman for about a year, taking her on ride-alongs and giving her a fake Drug Enforcement Administration badge, according to court records.
content: Suspicions arose last week when Sgt. Matthew Jacobsen of the Portland Police Bureau in Oregon saw a man and woman standing near a silver Dodge Charger with red and blue emergency lights and a tactical vest in its trunk with a “D.E.A. POLICE” patch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Thomas
title: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage includes luge, figure skating and skiing.
description: Bryce Bennett and Ryan Cochran-Siegle of the United States are medal hopefuls in the men’s downhill event.
content: Broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues in the United States on Sunday evening with events in ice hockey, men’s luge and figure skating. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Maybe There’s a Use for Crypto After All
description: Helium, a wireless network powered by cryptocurrency, hints at the practical promise of decentralized services.
content: One of the most frequent questions asked by crypto skeptics is: What can you actually do with crypto, besides financial speculation and crimes?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Alexander Bolshunov of Russia wins the gold in the men’s skiathlon.
description: Johannes Klaebo, the standout skier on Norway’s powerful team, had been a favorite going into the grueling race but never contended.
content: Alexander Bolshunov of the Russian Olympic Committee dominated the field to win the gold medal in men’s skiathlon, beating the field in the 30-kilometer race by more than one minute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Romer, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito and Elisheba Ittoop
title: The Sunday Read: ‘How A.I. Conquered Poker’
description: Good poker players have always known that they need to maintain a balance between bluffing and playing it straight. Now they can do so perfectly.
content: If you didn’t think poker and artificial intelligence could be bedfellows, think again. Keith Romer delves into the history of man’s pursuit of the perfect game of poker, and explains how the use of A.I. is altering how it is played: individuals using an algorithmic “solver program” to analyze potential weaknesses about themselves and their opponents, thus gaining an advantage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington and Matthew Futterman
title: Mikaela Shiffrin falls and is disqualified from the giant slalom.
description: Shiffrin was a favorite going into the event, but her fall seconds into her first run opened the door for other competitors.
content: Every Olympics delivers its own crushing surprises, the ill-timed pulled hamstring, the jump a figure skater fails to land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
title: Lata Mangeshkar, Bollywood’s Most Beloved Voice, Dies at 92
description: Ms. Mangeshkar, a revered figure in India, recorded songs for countless films — not appearing onscreen herself, but providing characters’ singing voices.
content: Lata Mangeshkar, who enthralled generations of Bollywood audiences as the singing voice behind many actresses’ performances, died on Sunday at Breach Candy Hospital in Mumbai, India. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Seaman Dies After ‘Hell Week’ of SEAL Training, Navy Says
description: Kyle Mullen of Manalapan, N.J., was one of two trainees who were hospitalized after completing several days of training outside San Diego.
content: One Navy SEAL candidate died and another was hospitalized after completing several days of excruciating training known as “Hell Week” in Coronado, Calif., Navy officials said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: How to Get Out of Bed and Start Running: Win the ‘Hero’s Minute’
description: How do you take that first step out the door? What’s the best way to approach a big running goal? Your training questions, answered.
content: Last month, we introduced you to a nutritionist, a physical therapist, a clinical psychologist, a coach and two American record holders to help you run your best this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Michael Crowley
title: The Crisis That Defined Blinken’s First Year
description: As the secretary of state enters his second year in office, Russia threatens, China looms and Afghanistan remains a challenge.
content: WASHINGTON — The arc of Antony J. Blinken’s first year as secretary of state could be broken down into two distinct eras: before and after Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Time For a Victory Lap*
description: *Some terms and conditions apply. Modern Monetary Theory, the buzziest economic idea in decades, got a pandemic tryout of sorts. Now inflation is testing its limits.
content: The sun was sinking low over Long Island Sound as Stephanie Kelton, wearing the bright red suit jacket she had donned to give a virtual guest lecture to university students in London that morning, perched before a pillow fort she had constructed atop the heavy wooden desk in her home office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Alan Blinder
title: Two Sports Injuries, Two Different Outcomes at Olympic Venues
description: An injured Polish athlete was slow to receive treatment after a training crash. The response was faster when a U.S. women’s hockey player was hurt.
content: BEIJING — The American doctor hardly waited once she arrived next to Brianna Decker, the women’s hockey player whose screams of distress filled a Beijing arena on Thursday night: the doctor looked past a penalty box and raised her hands to summon help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: ‘Taking the Voters Out of the Equation’: How the Parties Are Killing Competition
description: The number of competitive House districts is dropping, as both Republicans and Democrats use redistricting to draw themselves into safe seats.
content: WASHINGTON — The number of competitive congressional districts is on track to dive near — and possibly below — the lowest level in at least three decades, as Republicans and Democrats draw new political maps designed to ensure that the vast majority of House races are over before the general election starts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Katie Benner
title: California’s Supreme Court Was Split. Leondra Kruger Found the Center.
description: Known for her ‘elegant’ mind, the moderate judge, now on President Biden’s short list of potential high court nominees, could be a mediating force in Washington.
content: SACRAMENTO — In 2014, when then-Governor Jerry Brown nominated Leondra R. Kruger to the California Supreme Court, the immediate reaction in her home state was: Leondra who?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Shields Gets a Decision Win and Starts Promoting a Bigger Payday
description: Claressa Shields has lined herself up for a significant rematch against the woman who last beat her in an amateur bout in 2012. That fight against Savannah Marshall could happen later this year.
content: The post-fight showdown was about as textbook as the one-sided win by the undisputed middleweight champion, Claressa Shields, over her challenger, Ema Kozin, in Cardiff, Wales, on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Natalie Kitroeff
title: Haiti Opposition Group Calls on U.S. to End Support for Current Government
description: With tensions rising, many see Monday as a deadline for the government to step down.
content: A powerful Haitian opposition group is demanding the United States withdraw its support for the government of Prime Minister Ariel Henry in Haiti, saying the administration’s legitimacy is tarnished by delayed elections and Mr. Henry’s potential connection to the assassination of the country’s president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: A Climate Opportunity
description: Biden’s big climate goals depend on Congress.
content: President Biden promised to take serious action on climate change, and he set an ambitious goal to do it: halve the United States’ greenhouse gas pollution from its peak by 2030.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: In Yanqing, the Wind Blows and the Skiers Wait. And Wait. And Wait.
description: Weather has delayed Olympic skiing events before. But the unpredictable conditions in Beijing are raising concerns about scheduling, danger and fairness.
content: YANQING, China — The chatter about the wind started on Thursday, as soon as Matthias Mayer of Austria completed the first training run down the slope nicknamed “Rock.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Led by a 15-year-old, Russia’s team glides past the U.S. in figure skating.
description: Kamila Valieva of Russia had the highest score of the women’s short program, helping her team eclipse the United States, which had been in first place. Karen Chen of the United States fell.
content: As Kamila Valieva glided across the ice, a shower of camera shutters echoed through the Olympic figure skating arena. She was the skater to watch on the second day of the team event, and she delivered the performance many people had come to see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivien Schweitzer
title: George Crumb, Eclectic Composer Who Searched for Sounds, Dies at 92
description: Mr. Crumb wrote startling works, sometimes with political themes, and challenged musicians to employ new techniques, vocalize and move about the stage.
content: George Crumb, a composer who filled his works with a magpie array of instrumental and human sounds and drew on the traditions of Asia and his native Appalachia to create music of startling effect, died on Sunday at his home in Media, Pa. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Climate Change Enters the Therapy Room
description: Ten years ago, psychologists proposed that a wide range of people would suffer anxiety and grief over climate. Skepticism about that idea is gone.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — It would hit Alina Black in the snack aisle at Trader Joe’s, a wave of guilt and shame that made her skin crawl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Overhaul of Electoral Count Act ‘Absolutely’ Will Pass, Manchin Says
description: Senators working to overhaul the law said recent revelations about former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election made their work even more crucial.
content: WASHINGTON — Two senators working on an overhaul of the little-known law that former President Donald J. Trump and his allies tried to use to overturn the 2020 election pledged on Sunday that their legislation would pass the Senate, saying that recent revelations about the plot made their work even more important.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: What’s for Dinner? Probably Not London Porker.
description: In “Eating to Extinction,” Dan Saladino explores what the loss of local, nutrient-rich agriculture means for the planet.
content: EATING TO EXTINCTIONThe World’s Rarest Foods and Why We Need to Save ThemBy Dan Saladino
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Russia wins gold in team figure skating as Kamila Valieva hits two quad jumps.
description: Led by Kamila Valieva, the 15-year-old phenom, the Russian athletes secured the top spot; the U.S. got silver.
content: Russia won the team figure skating competition behind the performance of the 15-year-old phenomenon Kamila Valieva, whose history-making free skate on Monday included the first two quadruple jumps landed by a woman at an Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: The men’s downhill is postponed one day because of high winds.
description: Extreme weather has added to racers’ unease about the unfamiliar new racecourse outside Beijing.
content: The men’s downhill race at the Beijing Olympics on Sunday was postponed a day because of high winds, conditions that had contributed to competitors’ unease about a high-speed dash down an icy, unfamiliar racecourse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: How Great Minds Think
description: Rebecca Goldstein brings us a beast of a puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Monday, solvers, and welcome back to today’s constructor, Rebecca Goldstein, who is making her second appearance in the New York Times Crossword. As I know from making puzzles with her, Ms. Goldstein has a condition some crossword constructors refer to as “incurable theme brain”: She can take just about any phrase or mundane experience and turn it into a viable crossword theme with a tight, fully thought-out theme set. In fact, I think she can’t not do this with every phrase she comes across. It’s truly uncanny, and I find myself wondering not only how she learned to process information in this way, but also, why, given her incredible skills for wordplay, it took her until just this past year to start constructing puzzles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: The Olympics Begin
description: Plus Russia’s growing troop presence and Afghanistan’s collapsing health system.
content: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, opened the Beijing Games on Friday with a clear intent to celebrate his country’s increasingly assured global status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Just like that, the men’s 5,000 flips from an upset to a record.
description: Nils van der Poel came from behind to eclipse an Olympic record set hours earlier and claim Sweden’s first speedskating medal in a generation.
content: For 4,200 meters, it looked as if the National Speed Skating Oval would play host to one of the biggest upsets of the Olympics. But then, in a few strides, the potential upset reverted to the inevitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: Who Are We Caring for in the I.C.U.?
description: A doctor reckons with what’s owed to a patient’s family members.
content: We gathered as a medical team in front of my patient’s room early one Saturday. She was one of the sickest patients in the intensive care unit. Her lungs were destroyed by cancer and a rare reaction to her chemotherapy, and her condition worsened each day, despite aggressive interventions. It was clear that there was nothing more that we could do. Except to keep her alive until Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Charles Vert Willie, 94, Dies; Studied, and Defended, Racial Diversity
description: He devised a plan to desegregate Boston’s public schools. He also stood up against sexism in the Episcopal Church.
content: Charles Vert Willie, a sociologist whose work reshaped our understanding of school integration and Black family life, and whose stand against sexism in the Episcopal Church paved the way for the ordination of women priests, died on Jan. 11 at his home in Brighton, Mass. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: My Trans Journey: A History in 6 Passports
description: A trans woman’s passport photos show more than the countries she has visited.
content: Issued June 15, 1976
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Queen Elizabeth, Anchor in a Storm-Tossed Britain, Marks 70-Year Reign
description: The milestone puts the queen, 95, in rarefied company: Only three other monarchs are documented to have reigned for more than 70 years.
content: LONDON — Seventy years ago this weekend, a young English princess climbed into Treetops, a remote game-viewing lodge in Kenya, built into the limbs of a fig tree overlooking an elephant watering hole. The next morning, she came down as a queen, though she only learned of the death of her father, George VI, later that day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch, Weiyi Cai, Alexandre Devaux, Or Fleisher, Lazaro Gamio, Eleanor Lutz, Miles Peyton, Mark McKeague, Emily Rhyne, Bedel Saget, Joe Ward and Jeremy White
title: The Jumps That Gave Zoi Sadowski-Synnott Gold in Slopestyle
description: The 20-year-old from New Zealand won the Olympic title with a three-jump sequence that none of her rivals can match.
content: The 20-year-old from New Zealand won the Olympic title with a three-jump sequence that none of her rivals can match.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Truck Convoy Protests Descend on Major Canadian Cities
description: Demonstrations that began with truckers critical of vaccine mandates continued for a second straight weekend, as thousands across Ottawa, Toronto and Quebec City protested for a number of political causes.
content: Demonstrations that began with truckers critical of vaccine mandates continued for a second straight weekend, as thousands across Ottawa, Toronto and Quebec City protested for a number of political causes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should We Continue Online Religious Services?
description: Some praise an option that allows more people to join services, while a former priest worries about “an atomization of worship.” Also: The quest for knowledge.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Chocolate and almond tiger cake, miso ramen and more recipes.
content: Good morning. I loved Dorie Greenspan’s latest for The New York Times Magazine, a meditation on her life in Saint-Germain-des-​Prés in Paris, accompanied by a recipe that evokes the neighborhood’s patisseries. Her chocolate and almond tiger cake (above) is a kind of financier in cake form, a play on a recipe that’s run through with chopped chocolate and is known in pastry shops there as “tigré,” which means striped. (Dorie misread that the first time she saw it and has called the things “tiger cakes” ever since.)
source.name: The New York Times
